clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Control Trial on Computerized Cognitive Training for Individuals With Mild Cognitive Impairment

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of the study is to evaluate if working memory training is effective in improving working memory of MCI patients. Further, to evaluate if cognitive training relates to the function and structure of the brain.

detailed_description.textblock:
Introduction:
Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is a clinical condition characterized of a reduction in memory and/or other cognitive processes that are insufficiently severe to be diagnosed as dementia, but are more pronounced than the cognitive decline associated with normal aging. The prevalence of MCI ranges from 3% to 19% in adults older than 65 years; some of these individuals seem to remain stable or return to normal over time, but more than half progress to dementia within 5 year. Thus, MCI represents a critical window of opportunity for intervening and altering the trajectory of both cognitive decline and loss of functional independence in older adults. Impaired working memory (WM) is regarded as one of the core symptoms of patients with MCI. Recent studies have suggested that WM can be improved trough computer based WM training in early patients with alzheimer's disease and normal ageing population. However, there are still insufficient evidence regarding its effect on MCI.
Objectives:
The objective of the study is to evaluate if working memory training is effective in improving memory MCI patients. Further, to evaluate if cognitive training relates to the function and structure of the brain.
Patients and Methods:
The proposed study is a blinded, randomized and controlled trial that will include 120 elderly patients with MCI from the memory clinic. The groups will be randomized to either intervention or waiting-list group. The intervention is computerized working memory training performed for 60 minutes x 4 times/week over 24 weeks. Neuropsychological assessment will be administered at baseline and week 4, 12 and 24 after intervention. The structural and functional MRI, EEG and NIRS will be performed at baseline and week 24 after intervention for a sub-study on the effect of cognitive training on brain structure and function.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline composite working memory z score at week 24
primary_outcome.description: composite score of digit span and spatial span

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Changes from baseline composite CTP score at week 24
secondary_outcome.description: composite score of episodic memory, speed processing, executive function, attention, language and social cognition

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline self evaluated memory ability at week 24
secondary_outcome.description: Score on the questionnaire probes worries about memory (MMQ-contentment).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: change from baseline functional connectivity at week 24
change from baseline electrical brain activity at week 24
change from baseline cortical thickness at week 24
change from baseline cerebral blood flow at week 24
secondary_outcome.description: Cerebral blood flow measured with Near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline composite mood score at week 24
change from baseline serum BDNF level at week 24

secondary_outcome.measure: Composite of overall cognition z scores
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Changes from baseline composite overall cognition z score at week 24.
secondary_outcome.description: Score on Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) and Mini-mental State Examinatlon (MMSE).

arm_group.description: The training is considered 'adaptive', which means that the difficulty level of the tasks increases during the sessions according to the individual level of mastering for each participant, making the patient work at their maximum capacity at all times.

Participants in the control condition will conduct the same training as the intervention group after a 24-week waiting period. During the 24-week waiting period, the participants will receive assessment with the same protocol as the interventional group.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. An objective cognition impairment (a Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) score < 26)
2. Preserved general cognitive function( an mini-mental state examination (MMSE) score of > 24)
3. Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) = 0.5
4. Hamilton Depression Scale (HAMD) score of < 12
5. Intact activities of daily living (ADL score of <=26)
6. Schooling education > = 5 years)
7. Not meeting the diagnosis of dementia (according to the 10th revision of the International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems (ICD-10) and the National Institute of Neurological and Communicative Disorders and Stroke and the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association (NINCDS-ADRDA) Probable Alzheimer's Criteria
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Serious visual or hearing impairment;
2. Hachinski Ischemia Scale (HIS) >= 4;
3. Subjects with Axis I disorders listed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th Edition (DSM-IV), any other neurological disorders that could affect cognitive function;
4. currently on titration of medications with cognitive enhancers or antidepressants;
5. having any physical condition that could preclude regular attendance and full intervention-program participation
